403

3.26 Operation: Get Files Listing

3.26.1 Functional Behavior

Describe the functional behavior provided by this operation. Also add here any special considerations, assumptions, and dependencies for this particular operation
Gets a file list for a particular user

3.26.2 Call flow

Insert below a sequence diagram (ping pong) diagram in context to a complete call flow or transaction with numbered arrows and some description explaining the sequence as appropriate.

3.26.3 Version Impact Summary

Summarize the different versions of this operation that are in production or deleted by the current release of this service.
Service Version
Major or Minor Impact
Changes Introduced by this Version
1
Major
Initial Release

3.26.4 Authentication and Authorization

Describe OAuth model applicable to this operation.
Authorization Model
Subscriber Authorization required?
OAuth Scope Value
Brief Description
OAuth
authorization_code
Yes
LOCKER
  1. Redirect user to AT&T authorization page to capture User consent
  2. Obtain Token obtained using authorization code issued by the gateway alonf the client key and secret by making an Oauth token call with GrantType=authorization_code

3.26.5 Representation Formats

In the table below, describe supported representation formats for the request and response body. Where different versions support different formats, provide separate tables and indicate which versions apply to each table.
Direction
Supported Representation Formats
Request
N/A
Response
XML, JSON

3.26.6 Input Parameters

In the table below, describe input parameters. Where different versions support different input parameters, provide separate tables and indicate which versions apply to each table. The allowed values for the Location in Request column are: Header, Resource URI, Body or Query Parameter.
Parameter
Data Type
Req?
Brief description
Location
accept
String
No
Specifies the format of the body of the response. Valid values are:
  • application/json
  • application/xml
The default value is application/json. Per rfc2616: "If no Accept header field is present, then it is assumed that the client accepts all media types." By default our services return application/json.
Normal Accept header processing rules shall be followed according to rfc2616.
Note: If there is no entity body in a normal successful response, this parameter can still be specified to determine the format in the case of an error response message.
Header
accept-encoding
String
No
Specifies the accept encoding format. When this header is present, the gateway should compress the response to indicate the client that response is in compressed format. Valid values are: gzip
Header
authorization
String
Yes
Specifies the authorization type and token. "Bearer" + OAuth Token – access_token. If the authorization header is missing, the system shall return an HTTP 400 Invalid Request message. If the token is invalid the system shall return an HTTP 401 Unauthorized message with a WWW-Authenticate HTTP header.
Header
query
String
No
URL encoded search query. We recommend using the UTF-8 encoding scheme to obtain the bytes for unsafe characters. This is in keeping with the following W3 recommendation: http://www.w3.org/TR/html40/appendix/notes.html#non-ascii-chars
Query Parameter
before
String
No
Files added before or exactly at timestamp, if empty no lower time limit for search period, example: 2010-07-30
Query Parameter
after
String
No
Files added after or exactly at timestamp, if empty no lower time limit for search period, example: 2010-07-30
Query Parameter
limit
Integer
Yes
Specifies the max number of results returned.
Query Parameter
offset
Integer
Yes
Specifies the scroll set pointer on the results collection.
Query Parameter
orderBy
String
No
Specifies the sorting criteria. Valid values are: name, creationdate, contentsize, author
Default: name
Query Parameter
order
String
No
Specifies the sorting order. Constraints: asc, desc
Default: asc
Query Parameter
isCompressed
Boolean
No
Specifies that the result set will only contain the name of the media instead of the full details if set to true. Otherwise default result set.
Query Parameter

3.26.6.1 Request – Example (Get a file listing)

This demonstrates how to get a file listing.
GET /locker/v1/files?limit=20&offset=10&orderBy=author&order=desc HTTP/1.1 


Host: api.att.com


authorization: Bearer abcdef12345678


accept: application/xml

Folder Object

This table specifies the parameters that belong to the set object
Parameter
Data Type
Req?
Brief description
Location
id
String
Yes
Specifies the Id of the content object
body
name
String
Yes
Specifies the name of content
body
creationDate
String
Yes
Specifies the date of file creation in the system.
body
size
Integer
Yes
Specifies the size of linked content (bytes)
body
description
String
Yes
Specifies the description of the entry
body
count
Integer
Yes
Specifies the number of items
body

AV Object

This table describes the parameters that belong to the av object
Parameter
Data Type
Req?
Brief description
Location
status
String
No
Specifies the status, and the options are: pending, error, ok, infected, riskware, spyware, adware
body
detection
String
No
Specifies the detection name if infected, missing otherwise
body
message
String
No
Specifies the message for specifying state in case not clean, key missing otherwise.
body

3.26.7.1 Response – Example (Get file listing in XML)

This shows the response to a Get file listing in XML format.
HTTP/1.1 200 OK


content-type: application/xml 


content-length: 929 


date: Thu, 04 Jun 2010 02:51:59 GMT




<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>


<content>


    <count>1</count>


    <files>


        <file>


            <accessBlocked>false</accessBlocked>


            <av>


                <status>ok</status>


            </av>


            <contentSize>19152</contentSize>


            <creationDate>05-02-2011 14:07:57 +0000</creationDate>


            <description>UPDATING DESCRIPTION</description>


            <extension>xlsx</extension>


            <format>vnd.openxmlformats-officedocument.spreadsheetml.sheet</format>


            <id>112</id>


            <metadataList>


                <metadata>


                    <name>Author</name>


                    <value>Jackie Fong</value>


                </metadata>


                <metadata>


                    <name>Software</name>


                    <value>Microsoft Excel</value>


                </metadata>


                <metadata>


                    <name>Year</name>


                    <value>2010</value>


                </metadata>


            </metadataList>


            <name>3sScope.xlsx</name>


            <previews/>


            <collections/>


            <shareCodes/>


            <sharingBlocked>false</sharingBlocked>


            <tags/>


            <url>https://data.att-integration4.sdc.f-secure.com/data/1_0_0/object/?content_id=112&amp;ticket=1b0a8ae1-c17e-45d1-84bc-e110e1323434</url>


        </file>


    </files>


    <total>1</total>


</content>

3.26.7.2 Response – Example (Get file listing in JSON)

This shows the response to a Get file listing in JSON format
HTTP/1.1 200 OK 


content-type: application/json 


content-length: 624 


date: Thu, 04 Jun 2010 02:51:59 GMT




{


  "content": {


    "count": 1,


    "files": {


      "file": {


        "accessBlocked": false,


        "av": { "status": "ok" },


        "creationDate": "05-02-2011 14:07:57 +0000",


        "description": "UPDATING DESCRIPTION",


        "extension": "xlsx",


        "format": "vnd.openxmlformats-officedocument.spreadsheetml.sheet",


        "id": "112",


        "metadataList": {


          "metadata": [


            {


              "name": "Author",


              "value": "Jackie Fong"


            },


            {


              "name": "Software",


              "value": "Microsoft Excel"


            },


            {


              "name": "Year",


              "value": "2010"


            }


          ]


        },


        "name": "3sScope.xlsx",


        "sharingBlocked": "false",


        "url": "https://data.att-integration4.sdc.f-secure.com/data/1_0_0/object/?content_id=112&ticket=1b0a8ae1-c17e-45d1-84bc-e110e1323434"


      }


    },


    "total": 1


  }


}

3.26.8 HTTP Response Codes

List expected response codes (indicate any variation that exists across different versions):
Code
Reason Phrase
Description
200
OK
Successful response
400
Bad Request
Many possible reasons not specified by the other codes.
401
Authentication Error
Authentication failed or was not provided.
403
Forbidden
Access permission error.
404
Not Found
The server has not found anything matching the Request-URI. No indication is given of whether the condition is temporary or permanent.
414
Request-URI Too Long
The server is refusing to service the request because the Request-URI is longer than the server is willing to interpret.
500
Internal Server Error
The server encountered an internal error or timed out; please retry.
503
Service Unavailable
The server is currently unable to receive requests; please retry.

3.26.9 Service Exceptions

List the service exceptions generated by the operation (indicate any variation that exists across different versions):
MessageId
Text
Variables
Parent HTTP Code
SVC0001
A service error has occurred. Error code is <Error Explanation>
Error Explanation : <content here>
400
SVC0002
Invalid input value for Message part <part name>
part name : name of the input parameter that resulted in the error
400
SVC0003
Invalid input value for Message part <part name>, valid values are <part values>
part value : value of input parameter that was found to be in error.
400

3.26.10 Policy Exceptions

List the policy exceptions generated by the operation (indicate any variation that exists across different versions):
MessageId
Text
Variables
Parent HTTP Code
POL0001
A policy error occurred. For example, rate limit error, authentication and authorization error.
N/A
401,403
POL1009
User has not been provisioned for %1
System that hasn’t been provisioned
403

3.27 Operation: Delete Folder Files

3.27.1 Functional Behavior

Describe the functional behavior provided by this operation. Also add here any special considerations, assumptions, and dependencies for this particular operation
Remove files from a folder belonging to a user.

3.27.2 Call flow

Insert below a sequence diagram (ping pong) diagram in context to a complete call flow or transaction with numbered arrows and some description explaining the sequence as appropriate.

3.27.3 Version Impact Summary

Summarize the different versions of this operation that are in production or deleted by the current release of this service.
Service Version
Major or Minor Impact
Changes Introduced by this Version
1
Major
Initial Release

3.27.4 Authentication and Authorization

Describe OAuth model applicable to this operation.
Authorization Model
Subscriber Authorization required?
OAuth Scope Value
Brief Description
OAuth
authorization_code
Yes
LOCKER
  1. Redirect user to AT&T authorization page to capture User consent
  2. Obtain Token obtained using authorization code issued by the gateway alonf the client key and secret by making an Oauth token call with GrantType=authorization_code

3.27.5 Representation Formats

In the table below, describe supported representation formats for the request and response body. Where different versions support different formats, provide separate tables and indicate which versions apply to each table.
Direction
Supported Representation Formats
Request
N/A
Response
XML, JSON

3.27.6 Input Parameters

In the table below, describe input parameters. Where different versions support different input parameters, provide separate tables and indicate which versions apply to each table. The allowed values for the Location in Request column are: Header, Resource URI, Body or Query Parameter.
Parameter
Data Type
Req?
Brief description
Location
accept
String
No
Specifies the format of the body of the response. Valid values are:
  • application/json
  • application/xml
  • application/emma+xml
The default value is application/json. Per rfc2616: "If no Accept header field is present, then it is assumed that the client accepts all media types." By default our services return application/json.
Normal Accept header processing rules shall be followed according to rfc2616.
Note: If there is no entity body in a normal successful response, this parameter can still be specified to determine the format in the case of an error response message.
Header
accept-encoding
String
No
Specifies the accept encoding format. When this header is present, the gateway should compress the response to indicate the client that response is in compressed format. Valid values are: gzip
Header
authorization
String
Yes
Specifies the authorization type and token. "Bearer" + OAuth Token – access_token. If the authorization header is missing, the system shall return an HTTP 400 Invalid Request message. If the token is invalid the system shall return an HTTP 401 Unauthorized message with a WWW-Authenticate HTTP header.
Header
folderId
Integer
Yes
Specifies the id of the folder for which the file will be removed from.
URI Path
fileIdIds
Integer
Yes
Specifies the ids of the files that need to be removed from the folder.
Query Parameter

3.27.6.1 Request – Example (Delete 2 files from a folder)

This demonstrates how to delete files from a folder
DELETE /locker/v1/folders/2234456/files?fileIds=62588%2C55888 HTTP/1.1 


Host: api.att.com


authorization: Bearer abcdef12345678


accept: application/xml

3.27.7 Output Parameters

In the table below, describe output parameters. Where different versions support different output parameters, provide separate tables and indicate which versions apply to each table. Note: ‘consent’ refers to end user consent which may need to be obtained before data is returned,
Parameter
Data Type
Req?
Brief description
Location
content-type
String
Yes
Specifies the type of content of the body of the entity. Must be set to one of the following values:
  • application/xml
  • application/json
Note: If there is no entity body in a normal successful response, this parameter is still needed to specify the format in the case of an error response message.
Header
content-encoding
String
No
Specifies the type of encoding used on the data. Supported values are: identity or gzip
Note: If there is no entity body in a normal successful response, this parameter is still needed to specify the format in the case of an error response message.
Header

3.27.7.1 Response – Example (Successful response to deleting files froma folder)

This shows the response to deleting files from a folder
HTTP/1.1 204 No Content


content-length: 0


date: Thu, 04 Jun 2010 02:51:59 GMT

3.27.8 HTTP Response Codes

List expected response codes (indicate any variation that exists across different versions):
Code
Reason Phrase
Description
204
No Content
Successful response and the response does not include an entity.
400
Bad Request
Many possible reasons not specified by the other codes.
401
Authentication Error
Authentication failed or was not provided.
403
Forbidden
Access permission error.
404
Not Found
The server has not found anything matching the Request-URI. No indication is given of whether the condition is temporary or permanent.
414
Request-URI Too Long
The server is refusing to service the request because the Request-URI is longer than the server is willing to interpret.
500
Internal Server Error
The server encountered an internal error or timed out; please retry.
503
Service Unavailable
The server is currently unable to receive requests; please retry.

System that hasn’t been provisioned
403

3.28 Operation: Update File

3.28.1 Functional Behavior

Describe the functional behavior provided by this operation. Also add here any special considerations, assumptions, and dependencies for this particular operation
Modifies the information of a specific file belonging to the specified user. If a user attempts to update a file instance with a file instance with the same name, the original file instance is not overwritten. The new file instance is updated with the word copy appended to the name. The original file instance will be preserved.

3.28.2 Call flow

Insert below a sequence diagram (ping pong) diagram in context to a complete call flow or transaction with numbered arrows and some description explaining the sequence as appropriate.

3.28.3 Version Impact Summary

Summarize the different versions of this operation that are in production or deleted by the current release of this service.
Service Version
Major or Minor Impact
Changes Introduced by this Version
1
Major
Initial Release

3.28.4 Authentication and Authorization

Describe OAuth model applicable to this operation.
Authorization Model
Subscriber Authorization required?
OAuth Scope Value
Brief Description
OAuth
authorization_code
Yes
LOCKER
  1. Redirect user to AT&T authorization page to capture User consent
  2. Obtain Token obtained using authorization code issued by the gateway alonf the client key and secret by making an Oauth token call with GrantType=authorization_code

Data Type
Req?
Brief description

accept
String
No
Specifies the format of the body of the response. Valid values are:
  • application/json
  • application/xml
The default value is application/json. Per rfc2616: "If no Accept header field is present, then it is assumed that the client accepts all media types." By default our services return application/json.

Note: If there is no entity body in a normal successful response, this parameter can still be specified to determine the format in the case of an error response message.
Header
authorization
String
Yes
Specifies the authorization type and token. "Bearer" + OAuth Token – access_token. If the authorization header is missing, the system shall return an HTTP 400 Invalid Request message. If the token is invalid the system shall return an HTTP 401 Unauthorized message with a WWW-Authenticate HTTP header.
Header
content-length
Integer
No
Specifies the length of the content in octets. This header parameter is only required for the non-streaming request.
Header
content-type
String
Yes
Specifies the type of content of the body of the entity. Must be set to one of the following values:
  • application/json
  • application/xml
Header
fileId
Integer
Yes
Specifies the id of the file that needs to be updated
URI Path
file
Object
Yes
Contains the response information.

name
String
No
Specifies the name of the file
Body
description
String
No
Specifies the description of the file
Body
Need to check if the whole Content.File object is valid here!!

3.28.6.1 Request – Example (Update a file using XML)

This demonstrates how to update a file using XML.
PATCH /locker/v1/files/2234456 HTTP/1.1 


Host: api.att.com


authorization: Bearer abcdef12345678


accept: application/xml


content-type: application/xml




<file>


      <description>I LIKE THIS NEW DESCRIPTION better.</description>


</file>

3.28.6.2 Request – Example (Update a file using JSON)

This demonstrates how to update a file using JSON.
PATCH /locker/v1/files/2234456 HTTP/1.1 


Host: api.att.com


content-type: application/json


authorization: Bearer 38C2399A23999


accept: application/json




{


  "file": { 


      "name": "my_new_file_name"


  }


}

3.28.7.1 Response – Example (My First Response Example in XML)

This shows the response to a file update in XML format.
HTTP/1.1 200 OK


Date: Wed, 27 Apr 2011 14:11:31 GMT


content-length:539


content-type: application/xml




<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>


<file>


    <accessBlocked>false</accessBlocked>


    <av>


        <status>ok</status>


    </av>


    <contentSize>269</contentSize>


    <creationDate>Mon, 25 Apr 2011 19:30:55 GMT</creationDate>


    <description>UPDATING DESCRIPTION</description>


    <extension>txt</extension>


    <format>plain; charset=us-ascii</format>


    <id>39</id>


    <metadataList/>


    <name>guids.txt</name>


    <previews/>


    <collections>


        <folder>


            <count>1</count>


            <creationDate>Wed, 27 Apr 2011 19:58:10 GMT</creationDate>


            <description>I LIKE THIS NEW DESCRIPTION better.</description>


            <id>20</id>


            <name>Bunch of random Files Folder</name>


            <size>269</size>


        </folder>


    </collections>


    <shareCodes/>


    <sharingBlocked>false</sharingBlocked>


    <tags/>


    <url>https://data.att-integration4.sdc.f-secure.com/data/1_0_0/object/?content_id=39&amp;ticket=e8fca2ab-ee7f-404b-981d-ae792abd1585</url>


</file>

3.28.7.2 Response – Example (My second example response in JSON)

This shows the response to a file update in JSON format.
HTTP/1.1 200 OK 


content-type: application/json 


content-length: 624 


Date: Thu, 04 Jun 2010 02:51:59 GMT




{


  "file": {


    "accessBlocked": false,


    "av": { "status": "ok" },


    "contentSize": 269,


    "creationDate": "Mon, 25 Apr 2011 19:30:55 GMT",


    "description": "UPDATING DESCRIPTION",


    "extension": "txt",


    "format": "plain; charset=us-ascii",


    "id": 39,


    "name": "guids.txt",


    "collections": {


      "folder": {


        "count": 1,


        "creationDate": "Wed, 27 Apr 2011 19:58:10 GMT",


        "description": "I LIKE THIS NEW DESCRIPTION better.",


        "id": 20,


        "name": "Bunch of random Files Folder",


        "size": 269


      }


    },


    "sharingBlocked": false,


    "url": "https://data.att-integration4.sdc.f-secure.com/data/1_0_0/object/?content_id=39&ticket=e8fca2ab-ee7f-404b-981d-ae792abd1585"


  }


}

3.28.8 HTTP Response Codes

List expected response codes (indicate any variation that exists across different versions):
Code
Reason Phrase
Description
200
OK
Successful response
400
Bad Request
Many possible reasons not specified by the other codes.
401
Authentication Error
Authentication failed or was not provided.
403
Forbidden
Access permission error.
404
Not Found
The server has not found anything matching the Request-URI. No indication is given of whether the condition is temporary or permanent.
411
Length Required
The Content-Length header was not specified.
413
Request Entity Too Large
The size of the request body exceed the maximum size permitted.
415
Unsupported Media Type
The request is in a format not supported by the requested resource for the requested method.
500
Internal Server Error
The server encountered an internal error or timed out; please retry.
503
Service Unavailable
The server is currently unable to receive requests; please retry.

3.28.9 Service Exceptions

List the service exceptions generated by the operation (indicate any variation that exists across different versions):

A service error has occurred. Error code is <Error Explanation>
Error Explanation : <content here>
400
SVC0002

part name : name of the input parameter that resulted in the error

403

3.29 Operation: Get Upload Ticket

3.29.1 Functional Behavior

Describe the functional behavior provided by this operation. Also add here any special considerations, assumptions, and dependencies for this particular operation
The GET operation returns a session ticket for all containers owned by the authenticated sender of the request; this returns a ticket that should be used with any actions performed on the user’s behalf. The browser upload ticket is valid for upto 60 minutes.

3.29.2 Call flow

Insert below a sequence diagram (ping pong) diagram in context to a complete call flow or transaction with numbered arrows and some description explaining the sequence as appropriate.

3.29.3 Version Impact Summary

Summarize the different versions of this operation that are in production or deleted by the current release of this service.
Service Version
Major or Minor Impact
Changes Introduced by this Version
1
Major
Initial Release

3.29.4 Authentication and Authorization

Describe OAuth model applicable to this operation.

Subscriber Authorization required?
OAuth Scope Value
Brief Description
OAuth
authorization_code
Yes
LOCKER
  1. Redirect user to AT&T authorization page to capture User consent
  2. Obtain Token obtained using authorization code issued by the gateway alonf the client key and secret by making an Oauth token call with GrantType=authorization_code

Data Type
Req?
Brief description
Location
accept
String
No
Specifies the format of the body of the response. Valid values are:
  • application/json
  • application/xml
The default value is application/json. Per rfc2616: "If no Accept header field is present, then it is assumed that the client accepts all media types." By default our services return application/json.
Normal Accept header processing rules shall be followed according to rfc2616.
Note: If there is no entity body in a normal successful response, this parameter is still needed to specify the format in the case of an error response message.
Header
accept-encoding
String
No
Specifies the accept encoding format. When this header is present, the gateway should compress the response to indicate the client that response is in compressed format. Valid values are: gzip
Note: If there is no entity body in a normal successful response, this parameter is still needed to specify the format in the case of an error response message.
Header
authorization
String
Yes
Specifies the authorization type and token. "Bearer" + OAuth Token – access_token. If the authorization header is missing, the system shall return an HTTP 400 Invalid Request message. If the token is invalid the system shall return an HTTP 401 Unauthorized message with a WWW-Authenticate HTTP header.
Header
ttl
String
No
Specifies the time to live of this upload ticket in seconds. Valid values are 1-1800.
Default is 900
Query Parameter
type
String
Yes
Specifies the type of file (picture, video, music and file) that is being uploaded. The valid values are: P, V, M or F
Query Parameter
nonce
Boolean
No
Specifies a nonce. If present then the ticket is good for one time use only.
Default is false
Query Parameter

3.29.6.1 Request – Example (Get an upload ticket)

This demonstrates how to get an upload ticket and specifying the response to be in XML.
GET /locker/v1/tickets?type=P HTTP/1.1 


Host: api.att.com


authorization: Bearer abcdef12345678


accept: application/xml

3.29.7 Output Parameters

In the table below, describe output parameters. Where different versions support different output parameters, provide separate tables and indicate which versions apply to each table. Note: ‘consent’ refers to end user consent which may need to be obtained before data is returned,
Parameter
Data Type
Req?
Brief description
Location
content-type
string
yes
Specifies the type of content of the body of the entity. Must be set to one of the following values:
  • audio/wav (or audio/x-wav)
  • audio/amr
Header
content-encoding
string
No
Specifies the type of encoding used on the data. Supported values are: identity or gzip
Header
uploadTicket
Object
Yes
Contains the response information
Body
ticket
String
Yes
Specifies the ticket the is to be used for upload content
Body

3.29.7.1 Response – Example (Response to a Get upload ticket in XML)

This shows the response to a Get upload ticket in XML format.
HTTP/1.1 200 OK


content-type: application/xml 


content-length: 129 


date: Thu, 04 Jun 2010 02:51:59 GMT




<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?>


<uploadTicket>


    <ticket>dj8vzqmvhpy9y4JidJdpAU26NkdbF7OytGWoz82IDW0Qc</ticket>


</uploadTicket>

3.29.7.2 Response – Example (Response to a Get upload ticket in JSON)

This shows the response to a Get upload ticket in JSON format
HTTP/1.1 200 OK 


content-type: application/json 


content-length: 124 


date: Thu, 04 Jun 2010 02:51:59 GMT




{


  "uploadTicket": { 


      "ticket": "dj8vzqmvhpy9y4JidJdpAU26NkdbF7OytGWoz82IDW0Qc"


  }


}

3.29.8 HTTP Response Codes

List expected response codes (indicate any variation that exists across different versions):
Code
Reason Phrase
Description
200
OK
Successful response
400
Bad Request
Many possible reasons not specified by the other codes.
401
Authentication Error
Authentication failed or was not provided.
403
Forbidden
Access permission error.
404
Not Found
The server has not found anything matching the Request-URI. No indication is given of whether the condition is temporary or permanent.
405
Method Not Allowed
A request was made of a resource using a request method not supported by that resource (e.g., using PUT on a REST resource that only supports POST).
408
Request Timeout
The client did not produce a request within the time that the server was prepared to wait. The client MAY repeat the request without modifications at any later time.
414
Request-URI Too Long
The server is refusing to service the request because the Request-URI is longer than the server is willing to interpret.
500
Internal Server Error
The server encountered an internal error or timed out; please retry.
503
Service Unavailable
The server is currently unable to receive requests; please retry.

3.29.9 Service Exceptions

List the service exceptions generated by the operation (indicate any variation that exists across different versions):
MessageId
Text
Variables
Parent HTTP Code
SVC0001
A service error has occurred. Error code is <Error Explanation>
Error Explanation : <content here>
400
SVC0002
Invalid input value for Message part <part name>
part name : name of the input parameter that resulted in the error
400

3.29.10 Policy Exceptions

List the policy exceptions generated by the operation (indicate any variation that exists across different versions):
MessageId
Text
Variables
Parent HTTP Code
POL0001
A policy error occurred. For example, rate limit error, authentication and authorization error.
N/A
401,403
POL1009
User has not been provisioned for %1
System that hasn’t been provisioned
403

3.30 Operation: Delete Content

3.30.1 Functional Behavior

Describe the functional behavior provided by this operation. Also add here any special considerations, assumptions, and dependencies for this particular operation
Remove a file (meaning Media, Track or Object) belonging to a user from the digital locker.

3.30.2 Call flow

Insert below a sequence diagram (ping pong) diagram in context to a complete call flow or transaction with numbered arrows and some description explaining the sequence as appropriate.

3.30.3 Version Impact Summary

Summarize the different versions of this operation that are in production or deleted by the current release of this service.
Service Version
Major or Minor Impact
Changes Introduced by this Version
1
Major
Initial Release

3.30.4 Authentication and Authorization

Describe OAuth model applicable to this operation.
Authorization Model
Subscriber Authorization required?
OAuth Scope Value
Brief Description
OAuth
authorization_code
Yes
LOCKER
  1. Redirect user to AT&T authorization page to capture User consent
  2. Obtain Token obtained using authorization code issued by the gateway alonf the client key and secret by making an Oauth token call with GrantType=authorization_code

3.30.5 Representation Formats

In the table below, describe supported representation formats for the request and response body. Where different versions support different formats, provide separate tables and indicate which versions apply to each table.
Direction
Supported Respresentation Formats
Request
N/A
Response
XML, JSON

3.30.6 Input Parameters

In the table below, describe input parameters. Where different versions support different input parameters, provide separate tables and indicate which versions apply to each table. The allowed values for the Location in Request column are: Header, Resource URI, Body or Query Parameter.
Parameter
Data Type
Req?
Brief description
Location
accept
String
No
Specifies the format of the body of the response. Valid values are:
  • application/json
  • application/xml
The default value is application/json. Per rfc2616: "If no Accept header field is present, then it is assumed that the client accepts all media types." By default our services return application/json.
Normal Accept header processing rules shall be followed according to rfc2616.
Note: If there is no entity body in a normal successful response, this parameter is still needed to specify the format in the case of an error response message.
Header
accept-encoding
String
No
Specifies the accept encoding format. When this header is present, the gateway should compress the response to indicate the client that response is in compressed format. Valid values are: gzip
Note: If there is no entity body in a normal successful response, this parameter is still needed to specify the format in the case of an error response message.
Header
authorization
String
Yes
Specifies the authorization type and token. "Bearer" + OAuth Token – access_token. If the authorization header is missing, the system shall return an HTTP 400 Invalid Request message. If the token is invalid the system shall return an HTTP 401 Unauthorized message with a WWW-Authenticate HTTP header.
Header
ids
Integer
Yes
Specifies the ids of the content that needs to be deleted
Query Parameter

3.30.6.1 Request – Example (delete content)

This demonstrates how to delete content.
DELETE /locker/v1/content?ids=62588%2C55888 HTTP/1.1 


host: api.att.com


authorization: Bearer abcdef12345678


accept: application/xml

3.30.7 Output Parameters

In the table below, describe output parameters. Where different versions support different output parameters, provide separate tables and indicate which versions apply to each table. Note: ‘consent’ refers to end user consent which may need to be obtained before data is returned,
Parameter
Data Type
Req?
Brief description
Location
content-type
string
No
Specifies the type of content of the body of the entity. Must be set to one of the following values:
  • application/xml
  • application/json
Note: If there is no entity body in a normal successful response, this parameter is still needed to specify the format in the case of an error response message.
Header
content-encoding
string
No
Specifies the type of encoding used on the data. Supported values are: identity or gzip
Note: If there is no entity body in a normal successful response, this parameter is still needed to specify the format in the case of an error response message.
Header

3.30.7.1 Response – Example (My First Response Example in XML)

This shows the response to a profile creation in XML format.
HTTP/1.1 204 OK


content-length: 0


date: Thu, 04 Jun 2010 02:51:59 GMT

3.30.8 HTTP Response Codes

List expected response codes (indicate any variation that exists across different versions):
Code
Reason Phrase
Description
204
No Content
Successful response and the response does not include an entity.
400
Bad Request
Many possible reasons not specified by the other codes.
401
Authentication Error
Authentication failed or was not provided.
403
Forbidden
Access permission error.
404
Not Found
The server has not found anything matching the Request-URI. No indication is given of whether the condition is temporary or permanent.
405
Method Not Allowed
A request was made of a resource using a request method not supported by that resource (e.g., using PUT on a REST resource that only supports POST).
408
Request Timeout
The client did not produce a request within the time that the server was prepared to wait. The client MAY repeat the request without modifications at any later time.
414
Request-URI Too Long
The server is refusing to service the request because the Request-URI is longer than the server is willing to interpret.
500
Internal Server Error
The server encountered an internal error or timed out; please retry.
503
Service Unavailable
The server is currently unable to receive requests; please retry.

3.30.9 Service Exceptions

List the service exceptions generated by the operation (indicate any variation that exists across different versions):

3.31 Operation: Get Content metadata

3.31.1 Functional Behavior

Describe the functional behavior provided by this operation. Also add here any special considerations, assumptions, and dependencies for this particular operation
Retrieves file level metadata stored by Content Engine for one or more files

3.31.2 Call flow

Insert below a sequence diagram (ping pong) diagram in context to a complete call flow or transaction with numbered arrows and some description explaining the sequence as appropriate.

3.31.3 Version Impact Summary

Summarize the different versions of this operation that are in production or deleted by the current release of this service.
Service Version
Major or Minor Impact
Changes Introduced by this Version
1
Major
Initial Release

3.31.4 Authentication and Authorization

Describe OAuth model applicable to this operation.
Authorization Model
Subscriber Authorization required?
OAuth Scope Value
Brief Description
OAuth
authorization_code
Yes
LOCKER
  1. Redirect user to AT&T authorization page to capture User consent
  2. Obtain Token obtained using authorization code issued by the gateway alonf the client key and secret by making an Oauth token call with GrantType=authorization_code

3.31.5 Representation Formats

In the table below, describe supported representation formats for the request and response body. Where different versions support different formats, provide separate tables and indicate which versions apply to each table.
Direction
Supported Respresentation Formats
Request
N/A
Response
XML, JSON

3.31.6 Input Parameters

In the table below, describe input parameters. Where different versions support different input parameters, provide separate tables and indicate which versions apply to each table. The allowed values for the Location in Request column are: Header, Resource URI, Body or Query Parameter.
Parameter
Data Type
Req?
Brief description
Location
accept
String
No
Specifies the format of the body of the response. Valid values are:
  • application/json
  • application/xml
The default value is application/json. Per rfc2616: "If no Accept header field is present, then it is assumed that the client accepts all media types." By default our services return application/json.
Normal Accept header processing rules shall be followed according to rfc2616.
Note: If there is no entity body in a normal successful response, this parameter is still needed to specify the format in the case of an error response message.
Header
accept-encoding
String
No
Specifies the accept encoding format. When this header is present, the gateway should compress the response to indicate the client that response is in compressed format. Valid values are: gzip
Note: If there is no entity body in a normal successful response, this parameter is still needed to specify the format in the case of an error response message.
Header
authorization
String
Yes
Specifies the authorization type and token. "Bearer" + OAuth Token – access_token. If the authorization header is missing, the system shall return an HTTP 400 Invalid Request message. If the token is invalid the system shall return an HTTP 401 Unauthorized message with a WWW-Authenticate HTTP header.
Header
ids
Integer
Yes
Specifies a comma separate list of ids for which metadata should be retrieved for.
Max number of ids is 100
Query Parameter

3.31.6.1 Request – Example (Get a content metadata)

This demonstrates how to get metadata for content, and specifying the response to be in XML.
GET /locker/v1/content?ids=62588%2C55888 HTTP/1.1 


host: api.att.com


authorization: Bearer abcdef12345678


accept: application/xml

  • application/json

Object

id

body

body

String

body

String
Yes
Specifies the description of the entry
body

String
Yes

body

Specifies the download URL
body

String

body

Yes

body

No
Specifies the message for specifying state in case not clean, key missing otherwise.
body

3.31.7.1 Response – Example (Response to get content metadata in XML)

This shows the response to a get content metadata in XML format.
HTTP/1.1 200 OK


content-type: application/xml 


content-length: 929 


date: Thu, 04 Jun 2010 02:51:59 GMT




<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>


<content>


    <count>1</count>


    <mediaList>


        <media>


            <accessBlocked>false</accessBlocked>


            <collections/>


            <av>


                <status>ok</status>


            </av>


            <contentSize>88376</contentSize>


            <creationDate>01-01-2013 11:01:58 +0000</creationDate>


            <description>Whoa i'm hungry!</description>


            <extension>jpg</extension>


            <format>jpeg; charset=binary</format>


            <id>176</id>


            <metadataList>


                <metadata>


                    <name>ColorDepth</name>


                    <value>24</value>


                </metadata>


                <metadata>


                    <name>ColorSpace</name>


                    <value>Uncalibrated</value>


                </metadata>


                <metadata>


                    <name>Compression</name>


                    <value>JPEG</value>


                </metadata>


                <metadata>


                    <name>Dimension</name>


                    <value>356x283</value>


                </metadata>


                <metadata>


                    <name>Geometry</name>


                    <value>raster</value>


                </metadata>


                <metadata>


                    <name>Orientation</name>


                    <value>1</value>


                </metadata>


                <metadata>


                    <name>Resolution</name>


                    <value>72x72dpi</value>


                </metadata>


                <metadata>


                    <name>Software</name>


                    <value>Adobe Photoshop CS5 Windows</value>


                </metadata>


                <metadata>


                    <name>Year</name>


                    <value>2010</value>


                </metadata>


            </metadataList>


            <name>23.jpg</name>


            <previews>


                <preview>


                    <format>jpg</format>


                    <height>240</height>


                    <url>https://data.att-integration4.sdc.f-secure.com/data/1_0_0/media/?content_id=176&amp;ticket=ae4c5a25-a1d7-4f14-a292-c9ad64aee4f0&amp;preview=320x240xjpg</url>


                    <width>320</width>


                </preview>


                <preview>


                    <format>jpg</format>


                    <height>90</height>


                    <url>https://data.att-integration4.sdc.f-secure.com/data/1_0_0/media/?content_id=176&amp;ticket=ae4c5a25-a1d7-4f14-a292-c9ad64aee4f0&amp;preview=120x90xjpg</url>


                    <width>120</width>


                </preview>


                <preview>


                    <format>jpg</format>


                    <height>480</height>


                    <url>https://data.att-integration4.sdc.f-secure.com/data/1_0_0/media/?content_id=176&amp;ticket=ae4c5a25-a1d7-4f14-a292-c9ad64aee4f0&amp;preview=640x480xjpg</url>


                    <width>640</width>


                </preview>


            </previews>


            <shareCodes>


                <shareCode>a9fd0e52-51b6-4f8c-b25c-bbeb3f7cc4d6</shareCode>


                <shareCode>0e7264d8-1702-4ef7-9962-806573532135</shareCode>


                <shareCode>10ad5903-9d7d-4939-b011-ddb662f7f015</shareCode>


                <shareCode>c25eb52c-e4f6-4064-9c12-25573d1a2724</shareCode>


                <shareCode>2f4d84fa-0f45-4dc7-8536-147978172ef3</shareCode>


            </shareCodes>


            <sharingBlocked>false</sharingBlocked>


            <tags/>


            <url>https://data.att-integration4.sdc.f-secure.com/data/1_0_0/media/?content_id=176&amp;ticket=ae4c5a25-a1d7-4f14-a292-c9ad64aee4f0</url>


        </media>


</mediaList>


    <total>1</total>


</content>

3.31.7.2 Response – Example (Response to get content metadata in JSON)

This shows the response to a get content metadata in JSON format
HTTP/1.1 200 OK

content-length: 624 


date: Thu, 04 Jun 2010 02:51:59 GMT

  "content": {


    "count": "1",


    "mediaList": {


      "media": {


        "accessBlocked": "false",


        "av": { "status": "ok" },


        "contentSize": "88376",


        "creationDate": "01-01-2013 11:01:58 +0000",

              "height": "240",

              "width": "320"


            },


            {


              "format": "jpg",


              "height": "90",


              "url": "https://data.att-integration4.sdc.f-secure.com/data/1_0_0/media/?content_id=176&ticket=ae4c5a25-a1d7-4f14-a292-c9ad64aee4f0&preview=120x90xjpg",


              "width": "120"


            },


            {


              "format": "jpg",


              "height": "480",


              "url": "https://data.att-integration4.sdc.f-secure.com/data/1_0_0/media/?content_id=176&ticket=ae4c5a25-a1d7-4f14-a292-c9ad64aee4f0&preview=640x480xjpg",


              "width": "640"


            }


          ]


        },


        "shareCodes": {

            "a9fd0e52-51b6-4f8c-b25c-bbeb3f7cc4d6",

        "sharingBlocked": "false",


        "url": "https://data.att-integration4.sdc.f-secure.com/data/1_0_0/media/?content_id=176&ticket=ae4c5a25-a1d7-4f14-a292-c9ad64aee4f0"


      }


    },


    "total": "1"

}

3.31.8 HTTP Response Codes

List expected response codes (indicate any variation that exists across different versions):
Code
Reason Phrase
Description
200
OK
Successful response
400
Bad Request
Many possible reasons not specified by the other codes.
401
Authentication Error
Authentication failed or was not provided.
403
Forbidden
Access permission error.
404
Not Found
The server has not found anything matching the Request-URI. No indication is given of whether the condition is temporary or permanent.
405
Method Not Allowed
A request was made of a resource using a request method not supported by that resource (e.g., using PUT on a REST resource that only supports POST).
408
Request Timeout
The client did not produce a request within the time that the server was prepared to wait. The client MAY repeat the request without modifications at any later time.
414
Request-URI Too Long
The server is refusing to service the request because the Request-URI is longer than the server is willing to interpret.
500
Internal Server Error
The server encountered an internal error or timed out; please retry.
503
Service Unavailable
The server is currently unable to receive requests; please retry.

3.31.9 Service Exceptions

List the service exceptions generated by the operation (indicate any variation that exists across different versions):
MessageId
Text
Variables
Parent HTTP Code
SVC0001
A service error has occurred. Error code is <Error Explanation>
Error Explanation : <content here>
400
SVC0002
Invalid input value for Message part <part name>
part name : name of the input parameter that resulted in the error
400

MessageId
Text
Variables
Parent HTTP Code
POL0001
A policy error occurred. For example, rate limit error, authentication and authorization error.
N/A
401,403
POL1009
User has not been provisioned for %1
System that hasn’t been provisioned
403

3.32 Operation: Get Account Information

3.32.1 Functional Behavior

Describe the functional behavior provided by this operation. Also add here any special considerations, assumptions, and dependencies for this particular operation
Returns account information including usage, quota and a breakdown of images, movies, music and files. All are in bytes.

3.32.2 Call flow

Insert below a sequence diagram (ping pong) diagram in context to a complete call flow or transaction with numbered arrows and some description explaining the sequence as appropriate.

3.32.3 Version Impact Summary

Summarize the different versions of this operation that are in production or deleted by the current release of this service.
Service Version
Major or Minor Impact
Changes Introduced by this Version
1
Major
Initial Release

3.32.4 Authentication and Authorization

Describe OAuth model applicable to this operation.
Authorization Model
Subscriber Authorization required?
OAuth Scope Value
Brief Description
OAuth
authorization_code
Yes
LOCKER
  1. Redirect user to AT&T authorization page to capture User consent
  2. Obtain Token obtained using authorization code issued by the gateway alonf the client key and secret by making an Oauth token call with GrantType=authorization_code

3.32.5 Representation Formats

In the table below, describe supported representation formats for the request and response body. Where different versions support different formats, provide separate tables and indicate which versions apply to each table.
Direction
Supported Respresentation Formats
Request
N/A
Response
XML, JSON

3.32.6 Input Parameters

In the table below, describe input parameters. Where different versions support different input parameters, provide separate tables and indicate which versions apply to each table. The allowed values for the Location in Request column are: Header, Resource URI, Body or Query Parameter.
Parameter
Data Type
Req?
Brief description
Location
accept
String
No
Specifies the format of the body of the response. Valid values are:
  • application/json
  • application/xml
The default value is application/json. Per rfc2616: "If no Accept header field is present, then it is assumed that the client accepts all media types." By default our services return application/json.
Normal Accept header processing rules shall be followed according to rfc2616.
Note: If there is no entity body in a normal successful response, this parameter is still needed to specify the format in the case of an error response message.
Header
accept-encoding
String
No
Specifies the accept encoding format. When this header is present, the gateway should compress the response to indicate the client that response is in compressed format. Valid values are: gzip
Note: If there is no entity body in a normal successful response, this parameter is still needed to specify the format in the case of an error response message.
Header
authorization
String
Yes
Specifies the authorization type and token. "Bearer" + OAuth Token – access_token. If the authorization header is missing, the system shall return an HTTP 400 Invalid Request message. If the token is invalid the system shall return an HTTP 401 Unauthorized message with a WWW-Authenticate HTTP header.
Header

3.32.6.1 Request – Example (ET account infomation)

This demonstrates how to get account information, and specifying the response to be in XML.
GET /locker/v1/account HTTP/1.1 


host: api.att.com


authorization: Bearer abcdef12345678


accept: application/xml

3.32.7 Output Parameters

In the table below, describe output parameters. Where different versions support different output parameters, provide separate tables and indicate which versions apply to each table. Note: ‘consent’ refers to end user consent which may need to be obtained before data is returned,
Parameter
Data Type
Req?
Brief description
Location
content-type
string
yes
Specifies the type of content of the body of the entity. Must be set to one of the following values:
  • application/xml
  • application/json
Note: If there is no entity body in a normal successful response, this parameter is still needed to specify the format in the case of an error response message.
Header
content-encoding
string
No
Specifies the type of encoding used on the data. Supported values are: identity or gzip
Note: If tclhere is no entity body in a normal successful response, this parameter is still needed to specify the format in the case of an error response message.
Header
accountInfo
Object
Yes
Contains the response infomation.
Body

Account Object

This table specifies the parameters that belong to the account object
Parameter
Data Type
Req?
Brief description
Location
usage
Integer
Yes
Specifies how much space total used
Body
quota
Integer
Yes
Specifies how much space in CE is allocated for a particular user
Body
images
Integer
Yes
Specifies how much space all uploaded images is consuming
Body
movies
Integer
Yes
Specifies how much space all uploaded movies is consuming
Body
music
Integer
Yes
Specifies how much space all uploaded music is consuming.
Body
files
Integer
Yes
Specifies how much space all uploaded files is consuming.
Body

3.32.7.1 Response – Example (GET account infomation in XML)

This shows the response to a Get account infomation in XML format.
HTTP/1.1 200 OK


content-type: application/xml 


content-length: 929 


date: Thu, 04 Jun 2010 02:51:59 GMT




<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>


<accountInfo>


    <fileCount>8</fileCount>


    <files>4457066</files>


    <imageCount>43</imageCount>


    <images>72139885</images>


    <music>8165247</music>


    <quota>5368709120</quota>


    <trackCount>3</trackCount>


    <usage>86232895</usage>


    <videoCount>0</videoCount>


    <videos>0</videos>


</accountInfo>

3.32.7.2 Response – Example (GET account information in JSON)

This shows the response to a Get account infomation in JSON format
HTTP/1.1 200 OK 


content-type: application/json 


content-length: 624 


date: Thu, 04 Jun 2010 02:51:59 GMT




{


  "accountInfo": {


    "fileCount": 8,


    "files": 4457066,


    "imageCount": 43,


    "images": 72139885,


    "music": 8165247,


    "quota": 5368709120,


    "trackCount": 3,


    "usage": 86232895,


    "videoCount": 0,


    "videos": 0

}

Authentication Error

Forbidden
Access permission error.
404
Not Found
The server has not found anything matching the Request-URI. No indication is given of whether the condition is temporary or permanent.
405
Method Not Allowed
A request was made of a resource using a request method not supported by that resource (e.g., using PUT on a REST resource that only supports POST).
408
Request Timeout
The client did not produce a request within the time that the server was prepared to wait. The client MAY repeat the request without modifications at any later time.
414
Request-URI Too Long
The server is refusing to service the request because the Request-URI is longer than the server is willing to interpret.
500
Internal Server Error
The server encountered an internal error or timed out; please retry.
503
Service Unavailable
The server is currently unable to receive requests; please retry.

The operation will retrieve properties that will assist the application during setup.

Insert below a sequence diagram (ping pong) diagram in context to a complete call flow or transaction with numbered arrows and some description explaining the sequence as appropriate.

String

Specifies the format of the body of the response. Valid values are:
  • application/json
  • application/xml
The default value is application/json. Per rfc2616: "If no Accept header field is present, then it is assumed that the client accepts all media types." By default our services return application/json.

Note: If there is no entity body in a normal successful response, this parameter is still needed to specify the format in the case of an error response message.

String
No
Specifies the accept encoding format. When this header is present, the gateway should compress the response to indicate the client that response is in compressed format. Valid values are: gzip

String
Yes

3.33.6.1 Request – Example (Get a locker properties)

This demonstrates how to get locker properties, and specifying the response to be in XML.
GET /locker/v1/properties?version=1&userAgent=WinPhone HTTP/1.1 


host: api.att.com


authorization: Bearer abcdef12345678


accept: application/xml

  <count>1</count>

      <value>content.att.com</value>


    </property>


  </properties>


</lockerProperties>

    "count": "4",


    "properties": {

  }


}

System that hasn’t been provisioned
403

4 Structure of Exceptions

4.1 RESTful Web Services Exceptions

Two types of RESTful exceptions are supported:
  • Service Exceptions: These exceptions occur when a service is unable to process a request and retrying of the request will result in a consistent failure. For example, if an application provides invalid input.
  • Policy Exceptions: These exceptions occur when a policy criteria has not been met. For example, if (N+1)th request arrives when an application’s service level agreement only allows for N transactions per second.
Both service and policy exceptions contain the following elements:
Field Name
Data Type
Required?
Description
MessageId
xs:string
Yes
Unique message identifier of the format ‘ABCnnnn’ where ‘ABC’ is either ‘SVC’ for Service Exceptions or ‘POL’ for Policy Exception.
Exception numbers may be in the range of 0001 to 9999 where :
  • 0001 to 0199 are reserved for common exception messages
  • 0200 to 0999 are reserved for Parlay Web Services specification use
  • 1000-9999 are available for exceptions
Text
xs:string
Yes
Message text, with replacement variables marked with %n, where n is an index into the list of <variables> elements, starting at 1
Variables
xs:string [0..unbounded]
No
List of zero or more strings that represent the contents of the variables used by the message text.
An example is provided below:
HTTP/1.1 405 Method Not Allowed 
Content-Type: application/json
Content-Length: 12345
Date: Thu, 04 Jun 2009 02:51:59 GMT

{"RequestError":{
    "PolicyException":{
    "MessageId":"POL123"
    "Text":"The resource was invoked with an unsupported operation: %1.",
    "Variables":"PUT"}

}}
Notes:
  1. The response status code is provided on the first line.
  2. The appropriate content type is described on the second line.
  3. The RequestError structure in expressed in an appropriate format (e.g., JSON or XML).
  4. ‘RequestError’ contains either a ‘PolicyException’ or a ‘ServiceException’ structure.

5 Terms

Term
Description
API
In the context of this document, API is used to refer to a specific instance of operations identified specific URI.
Callback
In the context of this document, callback is used to refer to an API that is exposed by a 3rd party application and consumed by AT&T per a specification provided by AT&T.
Compatible
In the context of this document, compatible implies the API is available and responsive but it does not meet all aspects of compliance in one or more of these areas:
  1. URI
  2. Parameters
  3. Syntax
  4. Input and Output
  5. Success/Error Codes
  6. Behavior of API service
Compliance
In context of this document, compliance implies every aspect of the API implementation is fully compliant with the relevant specification.
Consumption Pattern
<<description needed>>
End-User
<< check marketing description or mCommerce team description>>
Method
In the context of this document, method is used to refer to an API that is exposed by AT&T to be consumed by a 3rd party application.
MSISDN
MSISDN is a number uniquely identifying a subscription in a GSM or a UMTS mobile network. Simply put, it is the telephone number to the SIM card in a mobile/cellular phone.
Operation
In the context of this document, operation is used to refer to a logical feature of the related service referenced in manner independent of whether it is characterized as a “method” or a “callback”. An operation is associated with one or more URIs. An operation may have multiple URIs if multiple provides offer the operation.
Examples of operations:
  • Send SMS
  • Receive SMS
Short code
Short codes (also known as short numbers) are special telephone numbers, significantly shorter than full telephone numbers, which can be used to address SMS and MMS messages from certain service provider's mobile phones or fixed phones.
Verbs
In context of this document, the term verbs refers to HTTP methods e.g. GET, PUT, POST,. per IETF RFC 2616.

6 Acronyms

Item
Description
ACR
Anonymous Customer Reference

Device Capabilities query

Device Location query

Data Type Document

Fully Qualified Domain Name

JavaScript Object Notation with Padding
MSISDN

Network Services Gateway

Representational State Transfer
SI
Service Indication
UE
User Equipment, for example the customer’s mobile device

URL

WAP
Wireless Application Protocol

7 Approvals

7.1 Assertion Checklist

By approving below the Project Manager, CSO, Dev Ecosystem and the Project Team assert that:
  • Data elements exposed by Northbound APIs described in this document have been reviewed for privacy / legal and security concerns.
  • The authentication and authorization approach meets current standards and best practices.
  • The API naming and scope is aligned with the service catalog.
  • The API design conforms to all other requirements of the Northbound API Practice requirements except where exceptions have been approved.
